contents.title: Installation
contents.description: The core package is available in npm

children.value: The core package is available in npm

props.code: npm install @language-kit/core
pnpm install @language-kit/core
yarn add @language-kit/core

contents.title: Simple usage
contents.description: Our goal will be making a simple language that convert the text to a LineNode[] array

children.value: Our goal will be making a simple language that convert the text to a
That are simple objects that tell us the content of each line of the text.
To do that we will need to define 3 classes for our language Nodes, Processors and a Parser
Is recommended to have an base node with shared methods, and sub nodes with specific methods
Tokens are simple javascript objects that represents the text.
You can know more about they in
Next we have to create an processor to convert tokens to this nodes
// search for the end of line token: token.type = "BreakLine"
// get all tokens until the end of line token
// add node instance to result nodes
// return true to indicate that the processor have processed some tokens and changed the state
Finally we can create an parser with the created classes.
Now we can parse any string and have an the output desired
BaseClass to use when creating nodes
Nodes are a representation of a group of tokens and/or other nodes.
When defining Nodes is highly recommended have well defined
patterns, this is to avoid problems and be more easy to implement your processor
The recommendation way to use this class is create your own
and then extend the others using this class.
The interesting thing is that it have an
This method return nothing by default
But the child classes can overwrite this method to output the correct html tags.
With this we have an standard of how to parse the nodes to html.

props.code:
const node = new MyNode()

node.setPositions()

children.value: If the language have children nodes you can overwrite this methods to also set the children nodes like the exemplo bellow.
Convert the array of nodes into text using

props.code:
const nodes = parser.toNodes('Hello')

nodes.toText() // Hello word
## Heading
Heading

children.value: BaseClass to use when creating processors.
A processor is an class that will be used by parsers to convert tokens into Nodes.
A recommendation when creating processors is to have one for each type
// verify is is a heading patter
// look for the end of the line that is Token.type === TokenType.BreakLine
// add the created node to the output and remove node tokens from the queue

contents.title: BaseParser
contents.description: Base class to use when creating parser.

children.value: Base class to use when creating parser.
You can customize the input overwriting the default methods
This is a utility class to help manage the nodes outputted by the parser
You can create an extended version of this class to help you manipulate better your nodes.
Check the markdown language example below.
to the array of nodes an overwrite the output of the main parser.
This way we have a very useful and easy way to convert all nodes in pure html, and also very customizable by individual nodes too.

props.code:
const nodes = parser.toNodes("# Heading\n **bold text**") const html = nodes.toHtml() //

Heading

bold text

const nodes = new NodeArray([NodeOne, NodeTwo])

nodes.setPositions()

props.code:
const nodes = parser.toNodes('Hello')

nodes.toText() // Hello word

children.value: Simple and Easy-To-Use Tools to build custom languages.
to extend an create your language in an
Base classes to extend and create your language in a OOP way
A lexer to convert plain-text into Tokens
An implementation of the tools for the markdown language

contents.title: Installation
contents.description: The package is available in npm

children.value: The package is available in npm

props.code: npm install @language-kit/markdown
pnpm install @language-kit/markdown
yarn add @language-kit/markdown

contents.title: Simple usage
contents.description: First just import the MarkdownParser class parser and instantiate the class

children.value: class parser and instantiate the class

props.code:
import { MarkdownParser } from '@language-kit/markdown'

const parser = new MarkdownParser()

children.value: to convert a plain text to nodes
This is the base class for creating the others markdown nodes.
Convert the node to Html text

props.code:
node.toHtml() //

Heading

# Heading 1 > level: 1
## Heading 2 > level: 2
### Heading 3 > level: 3

:: button

::

Plain-text containing what is inside the component
This is the attributes of the component
This indicate if is an inline component or not
Simple Node use to represent words and whitespace,
Is used when dealing with child nodes.
Convert the node to Html text
It just return the value in body without any Html tag

[This have a **bold text**]{ id="title" color="blue" }

class but with some helper methods

contents.title: Custom Nodes
contents.description: You can make your own processors and use together with the default processors to customize the output nodes

children.value: You can make your own processors and use together with the default processors to customize the output nodes
to know more details about processors
First you need to create your node class extending the base
Then you need to create a processor that extends the

class
and create the logic that process Tokens into Nodes
// all Hello word phase will be converted in a custom node
Finally you just need pass the custom processor to the MarkdownParser class and the output will be what we defined.
